title: Golf Terms Quiz
description: From birdies to bogeys, how well do you know the language of golf?

questions.question: In golf, what is an 'albatross'?
options: One stroke under par
Two strokes under par
Three strokes under par
Four strokes under par
questions.explanation: An albatross (also called a double eagle) is a score of three strokes under par on a single hole, an exceptionally rare achievement.

questions.question: What does 'bogey' mean in golf?
options: A score of one stroke over par
A score of two strokes over par
A score of even par
A score of one stroke under par
questions.explanation: A bogey is a score of one stroke over par on a single hole. A double bogey is two over par, and a triple bogey is three over.

questions.question: In golf, what is the 'fairway'?
options: The closely mown area between the tee and the green
The putting surface around the hole
The sand-filled hazard
The out-of-bounds area beyond the course
questions.explanation: The fairway is the closely mown strip of grass between the tee box and the putting green, considered the ideal area for play.

questions.question: What is a 'mulligan' in casual golf?
options: An informal do-over shot not counted
A course with extra holes
A penalty stroke
A type of iron club
questions.explanation: A mulligan is an unofficial, informal second chance to hit a shot without counting the first attempt, used only in casual play, never in tournaments.

questions.question: In golf, what is a 'dogleg'?
options: A stance used on uneven ground
A putting technique
A club with a curved shaft
A hole where the fairway bends sharply left or right
questions.explanation: A dogleg is a hole where the fairway angles sharply to the left or right, named because its shape resembles a dog's bent hind leg.

questions.question: What does 'fore!' mean when shouted on a golf course?
options: A player is teeing off on hole four
A warning that a ball is heading toward people
Play is about to resume
The match is tied
questions.explanation: 'Fore!' is a warning shout used to alert people nearby that a golf ball is heading in their direction and they should take cover.

questions.question: In golf, what is the 'rough'?
options: The paved cart path
The area of longer grass flanking the fairway
A damaged section of the green
The teeing ground
questions.explanation: The rough is the area of taller, thicker grass on either side of the fairway, making shots more difficult.

questions.question: What is a 'fade' in golf?
options: A type of golf club grip
A shot that rolls along the ground
A putt that stops short of the hole
A shot that curves gently from left to right for a right-handed golfer
questions.explanation: A fade is a controlled shot that curves gently from left to right (for a right-handed player). The opposite shot, curving right to left, is called a draw.

questions.question: In golf, what is a 'shank'?
options: A perfect drive down the center
A divot left on the fairway
A putt that lips out of the cup
A shot struck off the hosel of the club, sending it sharply sideways
questions.explanation: A shank is one of golf's most dreaded mis-hits, occurring when the ball strikes the hosel (the joint between the clubhead and shaft), sending it sharply to the right.

questions.question: What is a 'handicap' in golf?
options: The total par of the course
A numerical measure of a golfer's ability used to level competition
A physical obstacle on the course
A penalty for slow play
questions.explanation: A handicap is a number representing a golfer's potential ability, allowing players of different skill levels to compete fairly against each other.

questions.question: In golf, what is a 'links' course?
options: A coastal course on sandy, treeless terrain
A course connected to a resort
A course designed for beginners
A course with many water hazards
questions.explanation: A links course is a type of golf course built on coastal sandy ground, characterized by few trees, undulating terrain, and exposure to wind. The term comes from Old English for sandy ground.

questions.question: What is an 'eagle' in golf?
options: A penalty for hitting into a water hazard
A score of two strokes under par on a hole
The mascot of a golf club
A hole-in-one on a par three
questions.explanation: An eagle is a score of two strokes under par on a single hole, such as scoring a 3 on a par-5 hole.

questions.question: In golf, what is a 'bunker'?
options: A sand-filled hollow designed as an obstacle
A storage area for golf carts
An underground shelter near the clubhouse
A raised platform for spectators
questions.explanation: A bunker is a depression filled with sand, strategically placed as a hazard on the course. They are commonly found near greens and along fairways.

questions.question: What is a 'gimme' in golf?
options: A stroke awarded for a lost ball
A putt so short that other players agree it can be counted as made without being played
A warm-up shot before a round
A free club provided by the course
questions.explanation: A 'gimme' is a putt so short that fellow players concede it and allow the golfer to count it as holed without actually putting, used in casual play.

questions.question: In golf, what does 'the yips' refer to?
options: The sound of a ball hitting the cup
An involuntary wrist spasm causing missed putts
Celebratory shouts after a birdie
A cheer from the gallery
questions.explanation: The yips is a condition involving involuntary wrist spasms or freezing that affects a golfer's ability to putt, believed to be caused by anxiety and performance pressure.
